ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Clinical presentation of oscillopsia, pulsatile tinnitus, and Tullio phenomenon combined with low-frequency air-bone gaps, hypersensitive bone conduction, and lowered cVEMP thresholds.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing thresholds and identify air-bone gaps.
To evaluate middle ear status and rule out conductive pathology.
To assess the acoustic reflex arc; presence helps distinguish SSCD from otosclerosis.
To evaluate functional balance and sensory organization.
To assess saccular/inferior vestibular nerve function; lowered thresholds are a hallmark of SSCD.
Follow-up to monitor progression of hearing loss and air-bone gaps.
High-resolution imaging to confirm the presence of bone dehiscence over the superior canal.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiological testing revealed a 'pseudo-conductive' hearing loss in the left ear characterized by significant low-frequency air-bone gaps and hypersensitive bone conduction thresholds (-10 dB HL), despite normal tympanometry and acoustic reflexes. cVEMP testing showed a significantly lower threshold in the left ear (60 dB nHL) compared to the right, consistent with a third-window pathology. Vestibular function on VNG and CDP was normal.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal air conduction bilaterally. Significant air-bone gaps in Left ear (250-2000 Hz) and Right ear (250 Hz). Left masked bone thresholds at -10 dB HL.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal levels ipsilaterally and contralaterally.

tests.name: cVEMP
tests.result_summary: Left threshold 60 dB nHL, Right 75 dB nHL. 15 dB asymmetry (Left lower).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient returned 3 years later with worsening symptoms, including Tullio phenomenon. Audiometry showed widened air-bone gaps in the left ear compared to the initial visit. A repeat CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence on the left side.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Increased air-bone gaps in Left ear (e.g., 40 dB at 500 Hz) compared to 3 years prior.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: CNT (Could Not Test) due to fluctuating compliance.

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.result_summary: Revealed clear dehiscence (loss of bone) overlying the superior semicircular canal on the left side.

proposed_items: Surgical intervention (middle fossa or transmastoid approach) to plug or resurface the dehiscence
counseling_actions: Explain the 'third window' mechanism causing the air-bone gaps and hypersensitivity to bone-conducted sound
Explain that symptoms such as oscillopsia, pulsatile tinnitus, and Tullio phenomenon are caused by the dehiscence
Discuss surgical risks including facial nerve damage, decreased hearing, and vestibular damage

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for surgical evaluation of confirmed Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence given significant impact on quality of life.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor symptom resolution and hearing status.

expected_outcome: Definitive diagnosis was initially delayed due to poor quality of the original CT scan.
Increased air-bone gap on the audiogram after 3 years suggested an increase in the size of the dehiscence.
Patient described a notable increase in symptom severity that negatively impacted her quality of life.
